questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with insomnia comes to the physician because of nocturia and several years of difficulty initiating urinary stream. He often has the sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. Urinalysis is normal. He is started on a medication that can be used for both benign prostatic hyperplasia and post-traumatic stress disorder. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely to occur in response to this drug?



Blood pressure
Fluid retention
Pupil diameter
Bladder sphincter tone



A
Decrease
increase
decrease
decrease


B
Decrease
no change
no change
no change


C
Increase
no change
increase
increase


D
No change
no change
no change
increase


E
Decrease
decrease
no change
no change
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This set of findings can be observed with α-1 blockers (e.g., prazosin), which block α-1 adrenergic receptors expressed on vascular smooth muscle, pupillary dilator muscles, prostate, and bladder sphincter muscles, inducing smooth muscle relaxation. This causes a decrease in blood pressure with compensatory fluid retention, miosis, and also decreased bladder sphincter tone, meaning it improves the obstructive symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

See “Overview of alpha receptor antagonists” table.

B) INCORRECT:

This set of findings can be observed in phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (PDE-5) such as sildenafil, which inhibits the degradation of cGMP in smooth muscle cells lining the arterial wall in the corpus cavernosum of the penis and the lungs, inducing vasodilation. Therefore, it is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension. PDE-5 inhibitors have also been used to relieve the obstructive symptoms of mild to moderate BPH through their effect on the prostate and the bladder neck. They can cause hypotension when used in combination with alpha-1 blockers.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of findings can be seen with selective alpha-1 receptor agonists such as phenylephrine. Phenylephrine is a potent arterial vasoconstrictor and is most commonly used in the treatment of hypotension, but also can be used as a nasal decongestant or for priapism. Side effects include hypertension, reflex bradycardia, and mydriasis. Alpha-1 receptor agonists are not indicated for the treatment of BPH or PTSD.

D) INCORRECT:

This set of findings can be observed with oxybutynin, which is an anticholinergic drug that blocks muscarinic receptors. It decreases bladder detrusor muscle activity while increasing the bladder sphincter tone and is therefore commonly used for the treatment of overactive bladder. Even though potent anticholinergic drugs, such as atropine, can cause hypotension and mydriasis, oxybutynin has a minimal effect on blood pressure and pupillary sphincter tones.

E) INCORRECT:

This set of findings can be observed with loop diuretics and thiazides, which lower blood pressure and total body fluid by inhibiting sodium and water reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and distal tubule of the kidney, respectively. These drugs have no effect on pupillary diameter and bladder sphincter tone, unlike the α-adrenergic antagonist that was administered in this patient.
questions.hint: Prazosin is a drug commonly prescribed for benign prostatic hyperplasia and, less commonly, for sleeping disorders associated with PTSD. It is an adrenergic alpha-blocker.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of fatigue and difficulty initiating urination. He wakes up several times a night to urinate. He does not take any medications. His blood pressure is 166/82 mm Hg. Digital rectal examination shows a firm, non-tender, and uniformly enlarged prostate. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Finasteride is a 5-α-reductase inhibitor that blocks the hyperplastic growth of the prostate by inhibiting androgen synthesis. Though finasteride would be beneficial in the management of this patient's benign prostatic hyperplasia, it would not treat his hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Phenoxybenzamine is a sympatholytic drug commonly used pre-operatively in the management of pheochromocytoma. Because surgical manipulation of pheochromocytomas can release significant amounts of sympathetic hormones, nonspecific blockade of both α-1 receptors and α-2 receptors is necessary to prevent dangerous spikes in blood pressure intraoperatively and postoperatively. Phenoxybenzamine is not indicated for routine treatment of hypertension or to manage benign prostatic hyperplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is commonly administered in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Though tamsulosin is an antagonist on adrenergic receptors, its effect is selective for prostatic α-1A adrenergic receptors and α-1D adrenergic receptors. Tamsulosin has only a marginal effect on vascular α-1B adrenergic receptors and would not be the optimal treatment for this patient's hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Clonidine is a drug with sympatholytic effects. It is used to treat hypertension but most often in the setting of hypertensive urgency. Clonidine stimulates α-2 adrenergic receptors in the central nervous system and prevents further release of sympathetic neurotransmitters. However, clonidine does not have an effect on α-1 adrenergic receptors of the prostatic urethra and bladder neck.

E) CORRECT:

Terazosin is an α-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist that was initially used to treat hypertension (↓ vasoconstriction → ↓ blood pressure) and was later found to be useful for treating BPH as well (relaxation of bladder neck muscles → ↓ bladder outlet obstruction and easier micturition). This patient with hypertension and symptoms of BPH (i.e., hesitancy, nocturia, firm and enlarged prostate) would likely benefit from treatment with terazosin. Other medications that could also be used include prazosin and doxazosin.

See “Overview of sympatholytic drugs” table.
questions.hint: This patient's urinary symptoms along with the prostatic findings on physical examination suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). His blood pressure measurement is also diagnostic for hypertension.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for pain and swelling in his right foot. His temperature is 39.7°C (103.5°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 69/39 mmHg. A drug is administered via a peripheral intravenous line that works primarily by increasing inositol trisphosphate concentrations in arteriolar smooth muscle cells. Eight hours later, the patient has pain at the right antecubital fossa. Examination shows the skin around the intravenous line site to be pale and cool to touch. After discontinuing the infusion, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent further tissue injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Procaine is an ester-type local anesthetic that can be used for minor surgical procedures and spinal anesthesia. It has not been proven effective in managing extravasation caused by vasopressor agents.

B) CORRECT:

The ischemic tissue damage in this patient is caused by persistent vasoconstriction due to activation of α1 receptors by the extravasated pressor agent, which increases arteriolar smooth muscle IP3. As a short-acting, nonselective α-antagonist, phentolamine counteracts the α1 receptor-mediated vasoconstriction, improving blood flow to the damaged area and preventing further tissue loss. Terbutaline and topical nitroglycerin ointment may also be considered in cases of pressor extravasation.

See “Overview of sympatholytic drugs” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is an α1-antagonist that is most commonly used for the treatment of BPH. Tamsulosin acts selectively on α1A receptors in the prostate gland and has only minimal effect on peripheral vasomotor tone.

D) INCORRECT:

Conivaptan acts as an ADH inhibitor and is used in the treatment of SIADH. It has not been proven effective in managing extravasation caused by vasopressor agents.

E) INCORRECT:

Heparin is most commonly used for the treatment of thrombosis or embolic disease, which could also manifest with a cool, pale extremity. However, signs of ischemia restricted to the antecubital fossa, as seen in this patient, are more suggestive of ischemia due to vasopressor extravasation, in which case heparin would not be effective.

F) INCORRECT:

Midodrine is an α1 agonist that promotes vasoconstriction and is used for autonomic insufficiency and orthostatic hypotension. It would only worsen the symptoms of vasopressor extravasation in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient was given a vasopressor (most likely norepinephrine) for his hypotension. Vasopressors are not usually administered via peripheral IV lines because of the risk of vasopressor extravasation and local tissue necrosis.

questions.text: Which one of the following evaluations is most likely to reveal the cause of several falls preceded by lightheadedness in a community-dwelling older patient who is taking lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, doxazosin, and omeprazole for management of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease?

choices.text: Listen for bruits over the vertebral arteries
Check blood pressure while the patient is lying and standing
Evaluate the patient’s ability to stand on one foot
Perform a “Get Up and Go” test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Subclavian steal syndrome results from occlusion of the proximal subclavian artery causing retrograde flow in the vertebral artery away from the brain stem; symptomatic patients typically present with lightheadedness, hearing loss, or presyncope. These patients do not have a vertebral artery bruit but have diminished extremity pulses.

B) CORRECT:

A perception of lightheadedness that precedes a fall is suggestive of neurocardiogenic syncope.

Alpha-blockers are often used to treat symptoms of prostatism but can also increase the risk for orthostatic hypotension and falls, particularly in older patients. Checking for orthostatic hypotension is an appropriate first step in an older, community-dwelling patient with syncope or presyncope who is taking an alpha-blocker.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first step in evaluating an older, community-dwelling patient with syncope or presyncope who is taking an alpha-blocker is to check for orthostatic hypotension.

C) INCORRECT:

The inability to stand on one foot is indicative of muscle weakness or balance difficulties and is not a helpful sign in people with symptoms that are most suggestive of neurocardiogenic syncope.

D) INCORRECT:

Dysdiadochokinesia is the inability to perform rapid, alternating movements. It is caused by cerebellar dysfunction and would not be expected in a patient with symptoms most suggestive of neurocardiogenic syncope.

E) INCORRECT:

“Get Up and Go,” a simple test used to assess mobility, requires both static and dynamic balance. Presyncope is not a symptom of balance disturbance; therefore, a “Get Up and Go” test is unlikely to be diagnostic.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man presents with frequent dizziness on standing from a seated position. He has type 2 diabetes, stable coronary artery disease, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His current medications are finasteride 5 mg daily, doxazosin 2 mg daily, atenolol 50 mg daily, simvastatin 40 mg daily, metformin 1000 mg twice daily, and aspirin 81 mg daily.
His current resting blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg, and he has a heart rate of 65 beats per minute. After standing for one minute, his blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and he has a heart rate of 72 beats per minute. Examination of the heart and lungs is normal. An electrocardiogram is also normal.
Which one of the following changes in this patient’s medical regimen would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Alpha-1-adrenergic antagonists, which relax smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, are often prescribed for patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia; however, orthostatic hypotension is a relatively common side effect with two such agents — doxazosin and terazosin. Several other alpha-blockers (tamsulosin, alfuzosin, and silodosin) are more selective for prostate tissue and are thought to cause less orthostatic hypotension than doxazosin or terazosin. Doxazosin should be discontinued in a man with symptomatic orthostatic hypotension. If the orthostasis resolves and urinary symptoms worsen, a cautious trial of one of the selective agents could be considered.

Key learning point: The medication change that should be made for an older man with coronary artery disease, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and type 2 diabetes who has postural dizziness and who is taking finasteride, doxazosin, and atenolol is to discontinue the doxazosin.

B) INCORRECT:

Because this patient has diabetes, he is at increased risk for orthostatic hypotension secondary to autonomic dysfunction. Increasing salt and water intake or initiating the synthetic mineralocorticoid fludrocortisone would be appropriate treatment for selected patients with autonomic orthostatic hypotension. However, these treatments should be considered for this patient only if his orthostatic hypotension does not respond to withdrawal of the doxazosin.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers, such as atenolol, may contribute to hypotension through negative inotropy in patients with decompensated heart failure or by causing excessive bradycardia in patients with conduction system disease. However, beta-blockers generally do not cause profound orthostatic blood-pressure changes.

D) INCORRECT:

Finasteride reduces prostate size by inhibiting 5α-reductase. This drug does not cause orthostatic hypotension.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient has diabetes, he is at increased risk for orthostatic hypotension secondary to autonomic dysfunction. Increasing salt and water intake or initiating the synthetic mineralocorticoid fludrocortisone would be appropriate treatment for selected patients with autonomic orthostatic hypotension. However, these treatments should be considered for this patient only if his orthostatic hypotension does not respond to withdrawal of the doxazosin.
